Our Process

Github

The primary venue of collaboration between OpenStax and vendors is GitHub, where our code repositories and project management tools reside.

Our code repository is available (privately) at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

New collaborators

In order to gain access to the OpenStax repository, oer.exports, which holds our code and issue management tools, perform the following tasks:

  1. If you do not have a GitHub account, create one.

    • Go to http://www.github.com/.
    • Enter the requested information and click Sign up for GitHub.

  2. Send your GitHub username to Alana Lemay-Gibson nyxer@rice.edu, and Alina Slavik alinams@rice.edu.

    Our A-team will then setup your access to the Connexions / oer.exports repository. You will receive an invitation email from GitHub with a link to follow to accept access, or you may visit https://github.com/Connexions where you can find a link to accept access at the top.

  3. Visit the OpenStax repository at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

Report and track an issue with a textbook template

To submit an issue for an OpenStax textbook, perform the following tasks:

  1. Ensure that you are logged into GitHub:

    • If you are not logged into GitHub, the Sign in button displays in the upper, right corner of the page.
    • If you are logged into GitHub, your username display in the upper, right corner of the page.

  2. From the links menu on the top of the page, click Issues.

  3. Click New Issue.

  4. To create the issue, enter the following information:

    • At Title, enter a title for the issue. Please include the name of the textbook in the title, then use a colon and type a summary of the issue, e.g. "Economics: Feature titles 10 pixels too far left".
    • At no one is assigned, click the gear button and select nyxer95 to assign the issue to the Project Manager.

    • At Leave a comment, enter the following information:

      1. Rendition in which you encountered the issue, e.g. HTML, PDF, etc.
      2. Chapter and Module number.
      3. A detailed (quantitative and qualitative) description of the issue.

    • At Add Labels, click to select a value from all of the following label groups:

      1. book
      2. env
      3. prio
      4. type

    • Locate the screen captures of the issue and drag them into the comment section of the page.

      To ensure that your screen captures are inserted properly, click Preview.

    • Click Submit new issue

To track issues that you submitted, perform the following tasks:

  1. Go to https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports/issues?state=open.

  2. From Browse Issues, click Created by you.

  3. If you want to see only the issues related to a specific book, click one of the book labels.

Questions

If you have any questions about how to use GitHub to track issues related to OpenStax textbook development, please contact the Project Manager for OpenStax, Alana Lemay-Gibson, at nxyer@rice.edu

Content servers

A list of our servers and their purposes is available in our Textbook Team Servers document.

Report an issue with a content development staging server.

  1. Complete the following email template:
  2. Subject Line: URGENT: Work Stoppage on Textbook Staging Server

  3. Message Body: We don't have access to the server at address: _____________. It has been down for __ [minutes/hour(s)]. This is causing work stoppage.

  4. Include a brief statement of the nature of the outage (text or screenshot of the error message, etc.).

  5. Email the completed template to [partner name]@openstax.org.

Cc other members of your team as appropriate.

Limitations

One of our methods of improving access to education is lowering cost, and in our effort to do so we have adopted methods of textbook production which many may find unfamiliar. We rely heavily on technology that provides automated content layout and composition for print. This allows us to quickly change content and style, but it also leads to many unique problems. We will investigate some of those problems in detail.

A list of GitHub Issues which relate to these platform limitations is maintained using a status:wontfix label.

Page count

A large factor in textbook cost is the length of the text, and we have made the decision to sacrifice the quality of our layout and composition in order to lower student cost by reducing page count. This means that if a text is too long to print, we will adjust the style to lower the page count -- usually resulting in a lower quality textbook. Vertical space is extremely valuable, and should never be wasted. With regards to breaking this rule, only the most vital pedagogical features will be considered.

Our hardcover textbooks are limited to 1700 pages. We prefer a page count considerably lower, to increase accessibility and affordability.

While we acknowledge that white space, or negative space, is an active element in a good design, we have traded manual control of this type of pixel-perfect layout for software algorithms that place content into a paged layout quickly. This means that adding or removing whitespace can be difficult, or impossible, especially where content breaks across pages or where it has been set into multiple columns.

Column Layouts

Only specific content, such as collated material, can be organized into columns. The primary body text of each chapter is limited to one column. Markup and instruction will be provided in a tagging legend if a title supports organizing content into a column layout.

Text wrapping

Our platform does not support wrapping text around images.

Math and scientific notation

Our publishing platform does not completely support the features of the MathML language. We cannot use colors, certain roots outside the radical, or many features of vertical math. We have documented MathML Guidelines to help avoid some of these problems or introducing others.

Page breaking

  • Any kind of forced page breaks should be kept to a minimum. Without the ability to control placement of each piece of content individually, forcing elements such as tables or other varying length content to break will lead to unintended white space on a page and potentially increase page count significantly. Limiting forced page breaks also helps avoid problems if content is reused.
  • Chapters, appendices, and some collated material will appear after an automatic page break that will force such content to appear on an odd, right hand side, page.
  • Content is allowed to break within tables unless otherwise specified.
  • Content is allowed to break inside a feature unless otherwise specified.
  • Restrictions to natural content breaks may occur in exercises, examples, or other content. End of chapter material might have specific page breaking rules to ensure that exercise titles remain with the exercise problems. Sometimes breaks will be forced so that exercises flow evenly when in columns. These typically depend on the complexity of the layout and/or content.
Accessibility

Links

OpenStax content must conform to Level AA of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), version 2.0. Below are the most important guidelines that typically impact content development.

All links (intramodular, intermodular, external) within the content must conform to the following:

  • Guideline: 2.4.4 Link Purpose (In Context): The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context, except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in general. (Level A)
  • How to meet: Set anchor text for the link that accurately conveys its purpose.
    • Avoid anchor text such as: “This website”, “Video”, “ Click here”, etc.
    • Instead, use: “this page about Apollo 11 on NASA’s website”, “this video about kinetic and potential energy used in roller coasters”, etc.
  • Additional resources:
    • The page about link context from Wuhcag, a friendly site for folks developing accessible web content.

See Content Elements: Links for more information on link functionality and limitations.

Color Contrast

OpenStax content must conform to Level AA, of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), version 2.0. Below are the most important guidelines that typically impact content development.

Most images — exceptions noted below — must conform to the following:

  • Guideline: 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum): The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following: (Level AA)
    • Large Text: Large-scale text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1;
    • Incidental: Text or images of text that are part of an inactive user interface component, that are pure decoration, that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement.
    • Logotypes: Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no minimum contrast requirement.
  • How to meet: Use a light background with dark text or a dark background with light text. Use the color contrast checker to verify compliance.
  • Additional resources:
    • The page about color contrast from Wuhcag, a friendly site for folks developing accessible web content.

Non-Text Content

OpenStax content must conform to Level AA, of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), version 2.0. Below are the most important guidelines that typically impact content development.

All non-text content must conform to the following:

  • Guideline: 1.1.1 Non-text Content: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below. (Level A)
    • Controls, Input: If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a name that describes its purpose. (Refer to Guideline 4.1 for additional requirements for controls and content that accepts user input.)
    • Time-Based Media: If non-text content is time-based media, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content. (Refer to Guideline 1.2 for additional requirements for media.)
    • Test: If non-text content is a test or exercise that would be invalid if presented in text, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
    • Sensory: If non-text content is primarily intended to create a specific sensory experience, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
    • CAPTCHA: If the purpose of non-text content is to confirm that content is being accessed by a person rather than a computer, then text alternatives that identify and describe the purpose of the non-text content are provided, and alternative forms of CAPTCHA using output modes for different types of sensory perception are provided to accommodate different disabilities.
    • Decoration, Formatting, Invisible: If non-text content is pure decoration, is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technology.
  • How to meet:
    • Provide alternative text for images.
      • Most images only require short alt text, or “alt” of 32 words or less.
        • This is marked up as <media alt=”[insert alt text here]”>.
      • If the image cannot be described in 32 words or less -- for example, charts and graphs -- it requires both alt and a long description, or longdesc.
        • This is marked up as <media alt=”[insert alt text here]” longdesc=”[insert name of longdesc file here]”>, where the longdesc is a file, in .txt format, uploaded to our platform.
      • Example: <media id="eip-idm218242960" alt="An image comparing the autonomic functions of the parasympathetic nervous system to the central nervous system." longdesc="35-4-1-longdesc.txt">
      • Example test content
      • If an image contains both alt and longdesc, the alt should be 15 words or less. The longdesc can be as many words as are needed to convey the image in an accurate yet succinct manner.
        • The longdesc .txt file can take a table format if appropriate.
    • Provide text alternatives for audio and video.
  • Note: use null (alt="") for decorative images.
  • Additional resources:
    • The page about alternative text from Wuhcag, a friendly site for folks developing accessible web content.
    • This page on alt text from WebAIM.

Images of Text

OpenStax content must conform to Level AA, of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), version 2.0. Below are the most important guidelines that typically impact content development.

All images of text must conform to the following:

  • Guideline: 1.4.5 Images of Text: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text except for the following: (Level AA)
    • Customizable: The image of text can be visually customized to the user's requirements;
    • Essential: A particular presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed.
  • Note: Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are considered essential.
  • How to meet: Avoid images of text unless absolutely necessary.
  • Additional resources:
    • The page about images of text from Wuhcag, a friendly site for folks developing accessible web content.

Audio and Video Content

OpenStax content must conform to Level AA, of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), version 2.0. Below are the most important guidelines that typically impact content development.

There are several guidelines that pertain to audio and/or video content.

  • Videos must have a text transcript available. If a text transcript is not available, and writers feel that a video must be used, editorial partners must contact OpenStax to discuss contingency plans.
    • Relavant guideline:
      • Level A - Audio Description or Media Alternative
  • All videos with sound must have captions, either Closed Captioned or Live.
    • Relevant guidelines:
      • Level A - Closed Captioned
      • Level AA - Live Captions
  • Writers should try to select videos with an audio description available. This page has more information about audio descriptions.
  • Any content that is audio-only or video-only must follow the guidelines discussed on this page from Wuhcag.
General Composition

Color

OpenStax textbooks are primarily in four subjects: Mathematics, Science, Business, and Humanities. There are four general "themes" that specify the style for our titles in these markets.

Themes

Default

Mathematics

Science

Business

Humanities

Source Art

Source art should use colors from the primary palette from a specific markets theme.

Art

For art, general label for graphs, standard text (descriptions, labels, etc.), and numerals within the images should be Noto Sans. Any math numerals/symbols should be in STIX.

Size should vary based on size of the art. Font size should be no smaller than 6pt (for super and sub-scripts). We recommend keeping with the base size font for the title for consistency.

Typography

A double-stranded scale (Perfect Fifth and Perfect Fourth) is used to determine text sizes.

Base font size can be changed during production for a number of reasons, the most common being textbook length. Longer titles may require text to have less leading, or a smaller font size. Limiting text sizes to specific ratios, and determining vertical spaces relative to that text size, ensures that we can change text properties in a predictable way. All vertical spaces will adjust at the same ratios as text sizes change.

Mathematics

Mathematics is rendered using STIX Fonts Project fonts. These fonts are licensed SIL Open Font License (OFL-1.1).

Page Layout

Page dimensions are 8.5 x 11 inches. Top and bottom margins are 0.8 inch, left and right margins are 1 inch.

The page is split into margins, folio (page header and footer), and a content area. Numbers and generated content (such as surrent page number, current chapter title, etc) can appear in the folio areas. An attribution link is automatically added to the footer of all even-numbered pages.

Image Layout and Settings

Format

The original design files of all images/figures should be provided in AI, EPS, or PSD. For vector graphics EPS format is preferred.

Please maintain separate layers for each element in all source files for the ease of modification and maintenance.

Export settings

JPEG

All JPEGs including splash pages should be exported at 200DPI.

  • Color model: CMYK
  • Quality: 8
  • Compression method: Baseline
  • Resolution: 200DPI
  • Anti-aliasing: Type Optimized(Hinted)
  • Embed ICC profile: leave unchecked

PNG

All nested images inside features, notes and examples (items with a background color) should be provided in transparent PNG at 300DPI. In order for the integrity of the text in a transparent image to be maintained, the PNG needs to be exported at 300DPI.

  • Resolution: 300DPI
  • Anti-aliasing: Type Optimized(Hinted)
  • Interlaced: Checked
  • Background Color: Transparent
  • Font: Do not put a stroke around the font.

Size

Width

Images should be 2.1667in, 3.25in, or 6.5 inches wide. They should be cropped to one of these sizes, or extra white space should be added to the sides so that they fit into one of the width containers outlined here.

Height

Any extra whitespace at the top and bottom of figures should be cropped off. This cropping should not affect the content of the image.

Note: OpenStax does not restrict image height if the height is necessary for the context of the subject. We do recommend not using tall images, to reduce page count.

Multi Column Support

OpenStax does not currently support a multiple-column format, but in some cases we can allow a 2- or 3-column image. As long as the source art is one of the 3 sizes we require, the padding applied on these inline elements will shrink the images to fit the content.

Note: Shrinking the images using our scale rule should not distort content that may appear in source art as long as the font sizes used in such images follow our font-size rules.

Nesting

Padding

OpenStax adds equal padding (top, right, bottom, and left) to all features. This keeps content, including full-width images, from displaying at full width Our padding method uses a scale value that changes based on the font size, leading and line height properties. Adding both padding and the css rule box-sizing: border-box will resize the image to fit the content.
Content Elements

Folio

All OpenStax books have folio text at the top of the page on all pages after the table of contents. This text includes the number and title of the chapter (or Preface, Appendix, or Index) aligned to the inside of the page, opposite the page number. These folios are automatically generated in the pdf and cannot be edited manually.

Content Headers

OpenStax books use nested headers; they include chapter titles (H1), module titles (H2), inside-module section titles (H3), and further nested section headers (e.g. H4, H5). These header levels can be distinguished from each other by CSS-assigned font size and style.

Paragraphs

Paragraphs cannot be referred or linked to in OpenStax books, nor can they be indented without being enclosed by some other container.

Links

Our books use several types of links, each with different markup requirements: + External links, which go to a non-OpenStax website (usually with a forwarding shortlink from openstax.org), marked up with <link url="shortlink">anchor text</link>. + Intramodule links, which go to an element inside the same module as the link, and are marked up with <link target-id="id of the target element">anchor text</link>. + Extramodule links, which go to another module inside the book collection, marked up with <link document="other module number">anchor text</link> (these links may also go to a specific feature inside the other module, in which case the link markup will include target-id="id of the target element" inside the link tag)

Limitations

>, <, or curly quotes are not permitted in the anchor text. Emphasis (bold), italics, underline, etc. effects are also not supported. You can, however, use all other punctuation and straight quotes.

When to Use Anchor Text

  • Linking to modules: This will require using anchor text. We recommend using the module's title.
  • Linking to chapters: This will require using anchor text. We recommend linking to the introduction module of the chapter and using the chapter title as the anchor text.
  • Linking to a untitled list or a note: This will require using anchor text. Numbering not be pulled.
  • Linking to titled notes and lists: The title of the feature or note will be pulled. No anchor text required.
  • Linking to a section within a module: The default text that results is in the section called "Section Title". Anchor text will be required if you would like it to say just the title of the section.
  • Linking to equations, examples, figures, exercises, and tables: They will be numbered per the general OpenStax scheme (Figure 1.2, Table 3.2, etc). No anchor text is required.
  • Linking to an appendix: The default text that results is Appendix [Letter]. If you wish for the title of the appendix to appear, you will need to place it as anchor text.

Lists

Lists may be bulleted, unmarked, stepwise, numbered, alphabetical, or tokened. Certain lists may also be comma-separated and not vertically separated by item.

Blockquotes

Blockquotes are indented and may have a specified font style, and use the tag.

Code Example

 <blockquote>
  You're a wizard, Captain. - Deanna Troi
</blockquote>

Styled Example

You're a wizard, Captain. - Deanna Troi
Dividers

Footnotes

Numbered footnotes are available in OpenStax books with the <footnote> tag, which encloses the text of the footnote and moves it to the bottom of the page on which the tag appears.

Footer

Every even-numbered page of an OpenStax book has an automatically-generated footer stating the book’s free availability and location online.

Footer Image

Figures

A <figure> tag is a container for a media tag, and figures are numbered by default. To remove numbering from a figure, the unnumbered class must be applied in the figure tag (the markup is <figure class="unnumbered">), and an empty label tag (<label/>) must also be enclosed inside the figure tag. Figures may have captions (the markup <caption> goes inside the figure tag), but they are not required.

Figure Caption

Figures that have captions of 70 characters or fewer will allow the caption to fit within image dimensions as shown in sample A. The <figure> tags of these should use class=“small”. Otherwise captions will be the full width of the page.

Note: The 70 characters do not include the figure title or figure number; they are in addition to the title and number of the image.

Images

  • Images must be uploaded to the module they will appear in on the platform, and they show up in the content when referred to by filename in a <media> tag.
  • An alt text description of the image is required on each piece of media, for accessibility.
  • Images are unnumbered by default and do not have a caption, but can be numbered if enclosed by a figure tag.

Code Example

 <figure>
  <title>Orion Nebula.</title>
  <media alt="Photograph of the Orion Nebula. This image is dominated by large areas and bright swirls of glowing gas clouds, crisscrossed by dark bands of dust.">
    <image mime-type="image/jpeg" src="OSC_Astro_01_04_Nebula.jpg"/>
  </media>
  <caption>
    This beautiful cloud of cosmic raw material (gas and dust from which new stars and planets are being made) called the <term class="no-emphasis">Orion Nebula</term> is about 1400 light-years away. Features

  • Simple features: some features have an automatically-generated feature title (Try It, for example) which is provided by the CSS once a class is applied to the <note> tag enclosing the feature.
  • Subtitled features: some features have an automatically generated feature title as well as manually applied subtitles for each individual feature. These subtitles are sometimes applied in the <title> tag of the note, but other times they are text inside a paragraph in the note.
  • Features may or may not be numbered according to their class.

Code Example

 <note class="astronomy making-connections">
  <title>Astronomy and the Days of the Week</title>
  <para>The week seems independent of celestial motions, although its length may have been based on the time between quarter phases of the Moon. In Western culture, the seven days of the week are named after the seven “wanderers” that the ancients saw in the sky: the Sun, the Moon, and the five planets visible to the unaided eye (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn).</para>
  <para>In English, we can easily recognize the names Sun-day (Sunday), Moon-day (Monday), and Saturn-day (Saturday), but the other days are named after the Norse equivalents of the Roman gods that gave their names to the planets. In languages more directly related to Latin, the correspondences are clearer. Wednesday, Mercury’s day, for example, is <emphasis effect="italics">mercoledi</emphasis> in Italian, <emphasis effect="italics">mercredi</emphasis> in French, and <emphasis effect="italics">miércoles</emphasis> in Spanish. Mars gives its name to Tuesday (<emphasis effect="italics">martes</emphasis> in Spanish), Jupiter or Jove to Thursday (<emphasis effect="italics">giovedi</emphasis> in Italian), and Venus to Friday (<emphasis effect="italics">vendredi</emphasis> in French).</para>
  <para>There is no reason that the week has to have seven days rather than five or eight. It is interesting to speculate that if we had lived in a planetary system where more planets were visible without a telescope, the Beatles could have been right and we might well have had “Eight Days a Week.”</para>
</note>

Styled Example

Astronomy and the Days of the Week

The week seems independent of celestial motions, although its length may have been based on the time between quarter phases of the Moon. In Western culture, the seven days of the week are named after the seven “wanderers” that the ancients saw in the sky: the Sun, the Moon, and the five planets visible to the unaided eye (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn).

In English, we can easily recognize the names Sun-day (Sunday), Moon-day (Monday), and Saturn-day (Saturday), but the other days are named after the Norse equivalents of the Roman gods that gave their names to the planets. In languages more directly related to Latin, the correspondences are clearer. Wednesday, Mercury’s day, for example, is mercoledi in Italian, mercredi in French, and miércoles in Spanish. Mars gives its name to Tuesday (martes in Spanish), Jupiter or Jove to Thursday (giovedi in Italian), and Venus to Friday (vendredi in French).

There is no reason that the week has to have seven days rather than five or eight. It is interesting to speculate that if we had lived in a planetary system where more planets were visible without a telescope, the Beatles could have been right and we might well have had “Eight Days a Week.”

Examples

Examples may contain exercises with solutions (an <exercise> tag contains a <problem> tag, and may also contain one or more <solution> tags; <commentary> is another available child of the <exercise> tag). Solutions to exercises inside Examples have automatic numbering corresponding to the Example numbers. Examples may have subtitles, with either only a visual distinction (bolded manually in a paragraph enclosed inside the example), but the subtitles may also be created by applying specific classes to the <example> tag.

Code Example

 <example>
  <para>
    <title>Calculating Weight</title>
    By what factor would a person’s weight at the surface of Earth change if Earth had its present mass but eight times its present volume?
  </para>
  <para>
    <title>Solution</title>
    With eight times the volume, Earth’s radius would double. This means the gravitational force at the surface would reduce by a factor of (1/2)<sup>2</sup> = 1/4, so a person would weigh only one-fourth as much.
  </para>
  <para>
    <title>Check Your Learning</title>
    By what factor would a person’s weight at the surface of Earth change if Earth had its present size but only one-third its present mass?
  </para>
  <note>
    <title>Answer:</title>
    <para>With one-third its present mass, the gravitational force at the surface would reduce by a factor of 1/3, so a person would weight only one-third as much.</para>
  </note>
</example>

Styled Example

Example  3.3 . 
Calculating Weight

By what factor would a person's weight at the surface of Earth change if Earth had its present mass but eight times its present volume?

Solution

With eight times the volume, Earth's radius would double. This means the gravitational force at the surface would reduce by a factor of (1/2)2 = 1/4, so a person would weigh only one-fourth as much.

Check Your Learning

By what factor would a person's weight at the surface of Earth change if Earth had its present size but only one-third its present mass?

Answer:

With one-third its present mass, the gravitational force at the surface would reduce by a factor of 1/3, so a person would weight only one-third as much.

Tables

  • Basic tables are are numbered by default. Tables may have a title and/or a caption. The title appears after the table number and before the caption below the table.
  • To remove the numbering from a table, both apply the class="unnumbered" in the <table> tag and include an empty label tag (marked up as <label/> enclosed by the table tag).
  • To create a table with a header row, include a <thead> row before the other rows. Header rows are incompatible with a forced "Title" above a table within the same book.
  • To create a forced "Title" above a table instead the normal table title below it, merge the cells in the header row and put the "Title" in the merged cell. Tables with forced titles above the data can contain a caption, but no <title> tag is needed. These tables can be unnumbered. Forced titles above the data are incompatible with single header rows within the same book.
  • To create a forced "Title" above a table with a header row, use two <thead> rows, with the first one's cells merged. These tables can contain a caption, but no <title> tag is needed. Two-thead tables are incompatible with double-header-row tables within the same book.
  • To create a table with two header rows, use two <thead> rows, unmerged. These tables may have a caption and a title. They are incompatible with tables that have both forced "Title" rows above them and a header row, within the same book.
  • Unstyled tables use the class "unstyled" in conjunction with the class "unnumbered" (the markup is <table class="unnumbered unstyled">). These have no borders or styling and are aligned left by default.
  • To create a column header in a table, use the class "column-header" on the <table> tag.
  • To create "header" rows inside a table, merge the cells in the row and bold the text in the markup for the merged cell. More styling, such as colored text or colored background of the cells, is not supported by the platform.

Front Matter

Preface

The <document> tag of a preface must contain the preface class: <document class="preface">.

Table of Contents

The platform automatically generates a table of contents; it cannot be edited manually.

Chapter

Modules

Each chapter contains an introduction module. This module must use the class "introduction" (not "intro", which is a common markup mistake) in the document tag: <document class="introduction">. A chapter also contains one or more other modules. These are contained in a subcollection inside the collection structure. Modules may contain any available CNXML content.

Splash Image

At the beginning of each chapter in the introduction module, a figure with the splash class (markup: <figure class="splash"> may cover the horizontal width of the page.

Download sample splash image file

Chapter Outline

The platform generates a chapter outline for each chapter in the collection.

Learning Objectives

At the beginning of each chapter, and also at the beginning of each module, learning objectives are defined in the content, using a section with the class learning-objectives (the beginning of the module is marked up this way: <section class="learning-objectives">, with a bulleted list of objectives inside the section tag).

End-of-Chapter Collated Elements

  • Collating elements are created by adding a specific class to a <section> tag at the end of a module (these elements must always appear in the same order in the module markup). Collating elements common to most OpenStax books include Section Summary (class="section-summary"), Key Terms (class="key-terms"), Key Concepts (class="concepts"), Key Equations, various types of problems and exercises (often separated in collation by type). More flexible book-specific collated elements sometimes include Practice Tests and References.
  • Collating elements are usually located inside the relevant modules and collated together at the end of the chapter, using a collation instruction in the introduction module of each chapter. The collated elements may be separated by headers indicating the module they came from, or they may not, according to their class.

Answer Key

  • The Answer Key has exercise solutions that are separated by chapter in the back of the book.
  • Collation instructions for the Answer Key are included in the Introduction module of every chapter. There are two options; one will move any solutions inside the matched section to the end of chapter and add a copy of that to the answer key. Another will COPY any solutions inside the matched section to the answer key, also leaving it in place in the chapter.

References

  • May appear at the end of section, chapter, or book.
  • If displaying at the end of a book, they cannot be sorted at the book-level.

Appendix

  • Appendixes are titled with alpha numbering (instead of the arabic numeral default of the rest of the book), and all numbered elements inside (tables, figures)
  • The document tag must contain the class "appendix".
  • The folio displays usual page numbers and appendix titles (Appendix A for example) instead of chapter title.
  • The appendix styling is similar to the rest of the book.

Index

  • Index terms are based on how they are referenced in the text. They are marked up as <term>index word</term> and will appear emphasized (bold) in the. <term class="no-emphasis"> will result in the text within that tag registering in the index, but it will not appear emphasized (bold) in the text. Words that are similar, but not the same will appear as two separte entries, e.g. “bank” and “banks” would be separate entries.
